pageData.text: This investigation examines how components of mixtures can be separated by taking advantage of differences in physical properties. <button class=glossary-text>Paper chromatography</button> will be used to isolate food dyes found in different flavors of drink mixes. <button class=glossary-text>Chromatograms</button> of drink mixes will be compared to known chromatograms of FD&C dyes to identify which dyes are present in each mix.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Bottled or pure water, 1 pint*
Table salt (sodium chloride [NaCl])
Pencil (must be a pencil, not a pen)
Scissors
Paper towels
Aluminum foil or resealable plastic bag
White paper (8½ × 11")
Transparent tape
3 Coffee stirrers or toothpicks
M&Ms<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> candies, water soluble pen, or other colored item (optional)

pageData.altText:
Preparation – 30 minutes
Activity 1: Known FD&C Dyes – 30 minutes
Activity 2: Unknown Mixtures: Kool-Aid® Dyes – 30 minutes
Activity 3: Unknown household product – 30 minutes

pageData.text: *Bottled or purified water should be used to remove most of the solids that are found in tap water. Filtered water from a home water purifier (e.g., Brita® or PUR®) works well.

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: The Fundamentals of Chromatography

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Produce <button class=glossary-text>chromatograms</button> for known FD&C dyes (Red #40, Blue #1, and Yellow #5).
Produce chromatograms for three Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> samples (orange, grape, and strawberry).
Calculate the retention factor (R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub>) for each dye in the chromatogram.
Determine the dyes present in each Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> sample by comparison to the chromatograms of known dyes.

pageData.text: Drug testing happens every day for a variety of reasons. One common drug test methodology is liquid chromatography; a drug that this type of test can identify is peginesatide which is used to treat anemia in patients suffering from chronic kidney failure. This drug also leads to increased red blood cell production in the body, which results in more oxygen being provided to muscles. This can increase the stamina and overall performance of certain athletes, including non-human competitors. German scientists have discovered that LC-MS tests, designed to discover peginesatide in humans, can also test for the drug in horses, who can also benefit from its doping effects. In fact, the sensitivity for the LC-MS test allows it to indicate the presence of peginesatide in a horse’s system several days after it would have been initially administered<sup class=bodySupscript>1</sup>.

1Griffiths, F. (2012, August 16). Doping tests also work on horses. Chromatography Today.
https://www.chromatographytoday.com/news/hplc-uhplc/31/breaking-news/doping-tests-also-work-on-horses/21501#.Ymq0FmYHMTU.link

pageData.desc: A jockey riding a horse down a racetrack.
pageData.altText: A jockey riding a horse down a racetrack.

pageData.text: Color additives are an integral part of our lives. Used in foods, drinks, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, and toiletries, color additives make products appealing and appetizing. When we look at yellow candy, we think lemon; when we see red, we visualize and taste strawberry or cherry; the color orange reminds us of the fruit; green summons the taste of lime or mint. These colors can enhance the taste experience of artificial flavorings, which can be naturally colorless. In the United States, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) strictly regulates the dyes used in foods, drugs, and cosmetics. Once approved, they are given names and numbers. The names begin with “FD&C,” the abbreviation for the Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act of 1938 that granted the FDA authority to oversee safety in these areas. Only seven dyes have been certified as safe for use in foods, drugs, and cosmetics: blue #1, blue #2, green #3, red #3, red #40, yellow #5, and yellow #6. Yellow #5, also known as tartrazine, is the only dye that must be indicated on product labels because it causes an allergic reaction in a small percentage of people.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>An analysis of solution mixtures requires that components be physically separated and studied individually. One type of separation is <button class=glossary-text>paper chromatography</button>.

This analytical method separates very small samples of a mixture by dissolving them in a liquid known as a mobile solvent phase. As the solvent phase migrates up the stationary paper phase via capillary action, it comes in contact with a spot of a mixture containing one or more colored solutes. The spot dissolves into the mobile solvent and then moves up the paper with the solvent. The dissolved colored solutes separate according to differences in polarity. Since chromatography paper is highly polar due to the cellulose within it having multiple hydroxyl groups (–OH), polar solutes in the mobile solvent are attracted more readily by the paper and will therefore travel shorter distances before attaching to the paper’s surface. Less polar substances will spend more time in the mobile solvent and travel farther up the paper before attaching. This attachment to the paper’s surface is called <button class=glossary-text>adsorption</button> and in most cases each solute is a different color that aids in identifying the components. This separated pattern of components on the paper strip is called a <button class=glossary-text>chromatogram</button>.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes paper chromatography?

options.text: a method for physically separating the components of a mixture
a technique for dissolving solutes in solution
a method for increasing the adsorption rates of solutes on paper
the measure of the solute concentration adsorbed by paper
the movement of mobile solvent through paper

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Paper chromatography allows you to analyze solution mixtures by physically separating the components for individual study.

pageData.question: Which of the following mixtures is best analyzed by paper chromatography?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Paper chromatography separates very small samples of a mixture by dissolving them in a liquid known as a mobile solvent phase. Leaf pigments would be able to dissolve in the solvent and separate.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: An analysis of solution mixtures requires that components be physically separated and studied individually. One type of separation is paper chromatography. This analytical method separates very small samples of a mixture by dissolving them in a liquid known as a mobile solvent phase. As the solvent phase migrates up the stationary paper phase via capillary action, it comes in contact with a spot of a mixture containing one or more colored solutes. The spot dissolves into the mobile solvent and then moves up the paper with the solvent. The dissolved colored solutes separate according to differences in polarity.

pageData.question: What scientific principle is paper chromatography based upon?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The dissolved solutes separate according to differences in polarity.

pageData.question: A mixture is made up of two solutes. Solute A is less polar than Solute B. If the mixture is analyzed by paper chromatography, which of the following best describes the resulting chromatogram?

options.text: Solute A travels farther than Solute B
Solute B travels farther than Solute A
Solutes A and B travel the same distance
Solute A travels farther than Solute B if the solvent is polar
Solute B travels farther than Solute A if the solvent is polar

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Solute A will travel farther than Solute B because it is less attracted to the highly polar cellulose in the chromatography paper.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since chromatography paper is highly polar due to the cellulose within it having multiple hydroxyl groups (–OH), polar solutes in the mobile solvent are attracted more readily by the paper and will therefore travel shorter distances before attaching to the paper’s surface. Less polar substances will spend more time in the mobile solvent and travel farther up the paper before attaching.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Since chromatography paper is highly polar due to the cellulose within it having multiple hydroxyl groups (–OH), polar solutes in the mobile solvent are attracted more readily by the paper and will therefore travel shorter distances before attaching to the paper’s surface. Less polar substances will spend more time in the mobile solvent and travel farther up the paper before attaching.

pageData.text: One quantitative measurement used to further identify a solute adsorbed on the paper is the <button class='glossary-text'>retention factor, R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub></button>. This value is calculated as the ratio of the distance the solute moves up the paper to the distance the <button class='glossary-text'>solvent front</button> travels. This is a dimensionless number because the distance units in the numerator and denominator divide out during the calculation.
Rf = distance solute travels/distance solvent front travels

The R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> value is an integer less than 1 because most solutes are adsorbed before the leading edge of the solvent reaches the top of the paper. It can be used to further confirm the identity of an unknown solute when compared to known solute R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> values determined using the same solvent system, concentration, and type of paper.

pageData.question: On a chromatogram, if the solute moved 2.4 cm from the baseline and the solvent moved 11.9 cm, what is the retention factor, R<sub>f</sub>?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The retention factor is calculated by dividing the distance the solute travels by the distance solvent front travels.Rf = distance solute travels/distance solvent front travels

pageData.question: On a chromatogram, if the solute moved 3.8 cm from the baseline and the solvent moved 10.2 cm, what is the retention factor, R<sub>f</sub>?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The retention factor is calculated by dividing the distance the solute travels by the distance solvent front travels.Rf = distance solute travels/distance solvent front travels

This value is calculated as the ratio of the distance the solute moves up the paper to the distance the solvent front travels. This is a dimensionless number because the distance units in the numerator and denominator divide out during the calculation.
Rf = distance solute travels/distance solvent front travels

Rf = distance solute travels/distance solvent front travels

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. To start, prepare the Kool-Aid® solutions, sodium chloride solvent, chromatography strips, and microtip pipets. In Activity 1, spot each chromatography strip with a different FD&C dye. Then, place the strips in the solvent and allow the solvent to travel through the strips. Then, dry the chromatograms. Finally, for each chromatogram, measure the distances traveled by the solvent fronts and colored bands, and calculate the Rf value for each band. Spot each chromatography strip with a different Kool-Aid® solution. Then, place the strips in the solvent, allow the solvent to travel through the strips, dry the chromatograms, measure the distances traveled by the solvent fronts and colored bands, and calculate the Rf value for each band. Finally, identify the FD&C dyes present in each Kool-Aid® solution. Collect a dye sample from a food or household item, then create a chromatogram from the dye sample.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Procedure sections.

The Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> in this kit is not for human consumption. The packages have not been kept in a food grade facility and may be contaminated. Consider the Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> to be a laboratory chemical and not a food product. Use caution when working with FD&C food dyes and Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> solutions. They are nontoxic, but they can stain skin, fabrics, wood, and counter tops.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean the work area and all glassware thoroughly with soap and water after completing the investigation.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following molecules will travel the farthest in the mobile solvent phase during paper chromatography?
Calculate the retention factor (R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub>) value of a colored dye that traveled 52 mm on a chromatogram while the solvent front traveled 81 mm.
Why must the line of origin be drawn in pencil instead of pen on the chromatography strip?

options.text: The pen ink could dissolve in the solvent, adding extra bands on the chromatogram.
A pencil mark is lighter than a pen, and so easier to see.
A pen is more likely to tear the paper.
The polar nature of pencil lead keeps it from moving up the paper.
There is no reason to use a pencil instead of a pen.

assestmentData.question: In paper chromatography, what is the stationary phase?
The retention factor (R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub>) value is described using which of the following?
How will you determine the dye components of Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> in Activity 2?

options.text: Compare colors and R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> values between the Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> and food color chromatograms.
Compare solute distances traveled between the three Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> chromatograms.
Compare colors and R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> values between the three Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> chromatograms.
Graph the solute distance versus solvent front distance for each Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> color band.
Graph color versus R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> value for each Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> color band.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read through the procedure.
Obtain all materials.
Select a clean work area.
Use a weigh boat and electronic balance to weigh out 2.0 g of each Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> packet.
Transfer each to a labeled small cup. Add 5 mL of water and mix with the plastic spoon until completely dissolved.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for the other two Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> flavors. Be sure to rinse the spoon before mixing the next Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup>.
Prepare 100 mL of a 0.1% NaCl solution by adding 0.1 g of NaCl to 100 mL of bottled water.
Use the clean plastic spoon to stir the salt solution until the salt is completely dissolved.
Cut the six strips of chromatography paper in half lengthwise to make 12 strips and place them on a paper towel.
On each of the 12 strips, use a pencil to draw a line across the strip 1.5 cm from one end.
From the bottom of each strip, measure to 9.4 cm and draw a second line across the strip using the pencil.
At the bottom edge of each strip (below the 1.5-cm line), use the pencil to mark the exact middle of the strip.
With a pair of scissors, cut the strip into a “v” shaped point by starting at the middle mark and cutting diagonally in straight lines up to the right and left edges of the 1.5-cm line. See Figure 1.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagram showing how to cut the chromatography paper
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram showing how to cut the chromatography paper

pageData.text: On each of the six microtip pipets, measure 5 cm back from the tip, and cut each pipet with a pair of scissors. Discard the longer ends with the bulb. Save the 5-cm microtips for the lab as seen in Figure 2.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram showing how to cut the pipet
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing how to cut the pipet

pageData.text: Never use a pen to draw the lines or to mark the middle of separated colored spots. The ink could dissolve in the solvent and contaminate the component dyes.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>Never allow the solution spot applied to the paper be below the solvent level. The solvent must wick up the paper and go through the spot for proper separation of all dyes in the mixture.
In Activity 1, you will create chromatograms of three different FD&C food dyes to establish references to use in Activity 2.
On a paper towel, orient three chromatography strips parallel to each other with the pointed ends at the bottom.
Place either a small plastic bag or small piece of aluminum foil on top of another paper towel.

In one location on the plastic bag or aluminum foil, place two drops of the red #40 FD&C food coloring on top of each other from the dropper bottle. In two other locations, place two drops of the yellow #5 and blue #1 FD&C dyes respectively, such that the three different dyes are not touching.
Place one 5-cm microtip into the red drop, and allow it to partially fill the tip about 1 to 2 mm by capillary action. Lightly tapping the tip in the drop may help.
Touch the microtip to the middle of the line drawn at the 1.5-cm mark on the strip. Repeat the filling and application several times until the spot is fairly dark and is about 3 mm in diameter.
Repeat steps 4–5 using two clean 5-cm microtips and chromatography strips for the other two dyes.
Allow all three applied dots to dry for a few minutes.
Place three 17 × 100 mm test tubes into a test tube rack.
Add 20 drops (≈ 1 mL) of the 0.1% NaCl solution to each of the three test tubes. Place the drops in the center of the tube without allowing them to touch the walls.
Insert a straight pin into the middle of the top drawn line at 9.4 cm for each of the three chromatography strips. These will serve as hangers for the chromatography strips.
Carefully lower each of the chromatography strips with the applied dyes down into the center of each test tube, and place the tips into the NaCl-containing solvent.

Each strip should be straight and centered without touching the walls of the tube. Adjustments can be made by moving the straight pin forward or backward so that the paper does not touch the walls and impede the flow of solvent.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Allow the solvent to travel through the spot and move up the paper for 15 minutes.
Remove each of the strips and the straight pins, place them on a paper towel, and mark the leading edge of the wet with a pencil before it dries. (Figure 3)

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram showing how the distance traveled by a substance and the distance traveled by the solvent front should be measured on a paper chromatography strip
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing how the distance traveled by a substance and the distance traveled by the solvent front should be measured on a paper chromatography strip

pageData.text: When the strips are dry, mark the middle of the <button class='glossary-text'>colored bands</button> with a pencil.

Place the strips parallel to each other on the left side of a sheet of 8½ × 11" white paper, turned sideways. Tape the strips down with transparent tape. Label the bottom of each strip with its dye name and number.
Measure the distance in millimeters that the solvent front traveled from the origin line at the bottom. Record the distance in Data Table 1.
Measure the distance in millimeters that each colored band moved from the origin line to the mark in the middle of each color band. Record the distance in Data Table 1.
Calculate the Rf value for each of the bands and record them in Data Table 1.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Photograph the three FD&C chromatograms together. Make sure each is labeled with its dye name.
Keep the three test tubes containing the solvent for the Kool-Aid® analysis for Activity 2.
Rinse the 5-cm microtips with a little water for reuse in Activity 2. Fill the tip with clean water via capillary action and remove the water by dabbing it onto a paper towel.
If there is not enough time to complete the entire lab in one day, cover the three test tubes with plastic wrap to prevent evaporation of the solvent needed for Activity 2.

In Activity 2, you will create <button class=glossary-text>chromatograms</button> of three different Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> solutions to determine which FD&C food dyes are found in which solutions.
On a paper towel, orient another three chromatography strips parallel to each other with the pointed ends at the bottom.
Stir each of the previously prepared Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> solutions (orange, grape, and strawberry).
Place the end of a 5-cm microtip into the top of the orange Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> solution, and allow it to partially fill the tip by capillary action.
Touch the microtip to the middle of the drawn line on the bottom of the strip. Do this several times until the spot is fairly dark and is about 3 mm in diameter.
Repeat steps 3 and 4 with two clean 1.5-cm microtips and two chromatography strips, one for grape and one for strawberry Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup>.
Allow all three strips to dry.
Insert a straight pin into the middle of the top drawn line at 9.4 cm for each of the three chromatography strips. These will serve as hangers for the chromatography strips.
Carefully lower each of the strips with the applied spots down into the center of each test tube, and place the tips into the solvent.

Each strip should be straight and centered without touching the walls of the tube. The applied spot should be above the solvent. Adjustments can be made by moving the straight pin forward or backward.

pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol
pageData.text: Allow the solvent to wick up the paper and through the spot for 15 minutes.
Remove each of the strips and the straight pins, place them on a paper towel, and mark the leading edge of the <button class='glossary-text'>solvent front</button> with a pencil before it dries.
When the strips are dry, mark the middle of the <button class='glossary-text'>colored bands</button> that were deposited with a pencil.
Place the strips parallel to each other to the right of the known FD&C dyes on the same sheet of 8½ × 11" white paper. Tape them down with transparent tape.
Measure the distance in millimeters that the solvent front traveled from the origin line. Record the distance in Data Table 2.
Measure the distance in millimeters that each colored band moved from the origin line to the mark in the middle of the band. Record the distance in Data Table 2.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Photograph the three Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> chromatograms together. Make sure each is labeled with its flavor.
Calculate the Rf value for each of the bands and record them in Data Table 2.

Identify the dye(s) in each Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> sample by comparing the color and R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> values to those of the known FD&C dyes, and record the identity in the appropriate box of Data Table 2. R<sub class=bodySubscript>f</sub> values for the Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> samples may not exactly agree with the known standards, but the different colored bands should help to identify which FD&C dyes are present in the Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> samples.
In Activity 3, you will choose a different food product that contains a large amount of dye and perform color chromatography to identify its FD&C food dyes.

Activity 3 is an inquiry-based activity to apply the learned technique of chromatography via analyzing a product in your home. This requires the selection of a household product.All food has ingredient information on the packaging. Look for a food item containing several dyes and develop a method for extracting a highly concentrated sample of the dye(s). Some examples are M&M®-type candies and other highly colored candies. Use the smallest amount of warm water to extract as much food dye from the shell or candy for best results. Another option is to use a dark-colored, water soluble marker pen. Many of these also contain several different water soluble dyes. For this analysis, just tap the pen several times to create the ‘starting spot.’

Water-soluble inks of various colors, like those used in dry-erase markers, children’s markers, and overhead transparency pens, are excellent sources of dyes for chromatography analysis. White coffee filters can be cut into long rectangular strips as a substitute for chromatography paper if needed. The same test tubes and 0.1% NaCl solvent can be used as in the previous lab activities. The ink from a pen is applied as a spot on the origin line, 1.5 cm from the bottom of the strip of chromatography paper. Try black ink and see how many colors can be identified.

pageData.title: Disposal and Cleanup
text: Dispose of all microtip applicators.
Dispose of the plastic bag or aluminum foil containing drops of dyes.
Thoroughly rinse all cups containing Kool-Aid<sup class=bodySupscript>®</sup> samples and return to equipment set.
Pour the 0.1% NaCl solution down the drain, rinse the beaker with water, and return to equipment set.
Pour the contents of the three test tubes down the drain, rinse them with water, and place upside down on a paper towel to dry. Return to equipment set when dry.

In Activity 1, spot each chromatography strip with a different FD&C dye. Then, place the strips in the solvent and allow the solvent to travel through the strips. Then, dry the chromatograms. Finally, for each chromatogram, measure the distances traveled by the solvent fronts and colored bands, and calculate the Rf value for each band. pageData.content: Figure 1. Diagram for preparing chromatography paper strips

pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing how to cut the pipet
pageData.content: Figure 2. Diagram for preparing microtip pipets

pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing how the distance traveled by a substance and the distance traveled by the solvent front should be measured on a paper chromatography strip

data.title: Adsorption
data.content: In paper chromatography, the attachment of molecules to the paper’s surface

data.title: Chromatogram
data.content: The separated pattern of components on a paper strip in paper chromatography

data.title: Colored band
data.content: The visual evidence of a distinct solute in a chromatogram

data.title: Paper chromatography
data.content: An analytical method that separates very small samples of a mixture by dissolving them in a solvent

data.title: Retention factor, R<sub class='bodySubscript'>f</sub>
data.content: A dimensionless number that is calculated as the ratio of the distance the solute moves up the paper to the distance the solvent front travels

data.title: Solvent front
data.content: The furthest distance traveled by the developing solvent in paper chromatography
